title: 114_hr4370
content: The "Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016" may be cited as the Act. It includes an FMAP adjustment for affected jurisdictions equivalent to compact migrant expenditures. The "Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016" authorizes an FMAP increase for affected jurisdictions based on estimated compact migrant expenditures. The chief executive official must provide expenditure estimates to the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary of the Interior reviews the estimates before the beginning of the calendar quarter. The Secretary of Health and Human Services estimates the FMAP increase needed for affected jurisdictions to cover compact migrant expenditures, equivalent to the final estimated amount submitted by the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary of Health and Human Services notifies chief executive officials of FMAP increases for affected jurisdictions, ensuring payments do not exceed limitations under title XIX of the Social Security Act. Additionally, affected jurisdictions must report on reconciling and payment adjustments. For each calendar quarter with an FMAP increase, affected jurisdictions must report total compact migrant expenditures to the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary reviews and adjusts the accounting before submitting a final report for each jurisdiction. The Secretary of Health and Human Services reviews and adjusts the FMAP increase for affected jurisdictions based on compact migrant expenditures reported, making appropriate adjustments subject to limitations. The FMAP for affected jurisdictions is adjusted for overpayments or underpayments in future quarters. The increase in FMAP cannot exceed 100 percent. Compact migrant expenditures are not considered medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act. The term "affected jurisdiction" is defined in the Compact of Free Association Amendments Act. Compact migrant expenditures refer to non-Federal funds spent by affected jurisdictions on items and services for qualified nonimmigrants, as defined in the Compact of Free Association Amendments Act of 2003. This includes payments to healthcare providers for services provided to qualified nonimmigrants. The term "FMAP" refers to the Federal medical assistance percentage under the Social Security Act. A conforming amendment to the Act includes a reference to the Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016. SEC. 3. PAYMENTS RELATING TO ELEMENTARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION OF CITIZENS OF FREELY ASSOCIATED STATES. Amendment to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 includes educating alien children from Freely Associated States. Payment amendments for eligible federally connected children also include those who have resided in the United States. Amendment to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 includes additional funding for eligible federally connected children, specifically those who have resided in the United States as citizens of the Republic of the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, or the Republic of Palau. This amendment authorizes $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2017 and each succeeding fiscal year to support these children. SEC. 4 amends the Housing and Community Development Act to give preference to US citizens or nationals over aliens for housing financial assistance in Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands. SEC. 5 calls for an independent assessment of the strategic relationship between the US and the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau. The Secretary of State is required to seek an agreement with an eligible organization to conduct an independent assessment of the strategic importance of the relationship between the United States and the Republic of the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, and the Republic of Palau. This assessment includes evaluating the relationships as part of the Asia-Pacific re-balance, assessing the capabilities of US Government agencies in administering the Compact of Free Association. The eligible organization will assess the Compact of Free Association between the United States and the Republic of the Marshall Islands, Federated States of Micronesia, and Republic of Palau. Recommendations on improvements, renewal of Compacts, and other relevant matters will be reported within one year. The eligible organization entering an agreement under this Act must submit a report to the Secretary of State, including the required assessment, specified matters, and any additional relevant information. The report should be in unclassified form but may include a classified annex if needed. The organization can obtain necessary information from US departments or agencies to fulfill the requirements of the agreement. The head of the department or agency must provide information to the eligible organization.
